title: Bump Rust port to 0.6.1

title: [Swift] Adds Small Code Gen improvements
body:
The following PR includes the following improvements:
- Adds Min and max values into enums which is also implemented in cpp
- Adds all of swift's keywords into the code gen
- Adds comments into the generated code, using the cpp comment function.

title: [Go] Implements a SharedStrings function
body:
The following PR creates a sharedString function by implementing a hashmap that would save the offset of seen strings and returns them if we see a duplicate entry, just like the cpp, csharp implementation.
Closes #5731

title: Add vcpkg installation instructions
body:
Flatbuffers is available as a port in VCPKG , documenting the install process here will help users get started by providing a single set of commands to build flatbuffers, ready to be included in their projects.

VCPKG is a C++ library manager that simplifies installation for flatbuffers and other project dependencies, we also test whether our library ports build in various configurations (dynamic, static) on various platforms (OSX, Linux, Windows: x86, x64, UWP, ARM) to keep a wide coverage for users.

I'm a maintainer for vcpkg, and here is what the port script looks like. We try to keep the library maintained as close as possible to the original library.

title: [Swift] Adds validation for flatbuffers version
body: This following PR adds a version enum that will be maintained according to the FlatBuffers version in release. The current one is v1.11.1. The code gen will create a function in all the structs and tables to validate it if the user wishes to do so

title: [Dart] Fix deprecated field support, inf/nan
body:
Fixes the following:

- Previous code assumed that the fields vector would not end in a deprecated field, leading to several points where invalid code could be generated (e.g. missing a trailing paren/bracket).
- Previous code assumed that there would be at least one non-deprecated field if there were any fields, leading to invalid code generation
- Previous code did not handle `+/-inf` or `nan` default constants properly.

Fixes #5712

title: [Java][FlexBuffers] Deprecate typed vector strings due to design flaw
body:
It will still be possible to read buffers with this type, but the
elements will be treated as FBT_KEY and will be read as null-terminated
string.

Trying to build a vector of strings as typed will throw an exception.

More information on https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/issues/5627

Also, fix another bug on strings, where long strings were not properly
aligned.

title: [Swift] Fix padding function overflow when bufSize is 0
body:
Hi, there

please review it, thanks.

title: [typescript] Size-prefixed root accessors not taking into account size prefix
body:
It seems the size-prefixed root accessors aren't taking into account the size prefix.

I'm not sure if this is the right fix, but 

Also, this change adds parentheses after new object expressions for Typescript generated code. (ie, `new MyGame.Example.Monster()` instead of `new MyGame.Example.Monster`).

title: [Go] Replace references to hardcoded ”Monster" etc with idiomatic go wherever possible
body:
Most details of the need for this PR were already discussed in Issue https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/issues/5668.

I have also (additionally) converted the generated union types' UnPack func into a method.

e.g.
Generated func:
```go
func AnyUnPack(t Any, table flatbuffers.Table) *AnyT
```

Becomes method,
```go
func (rcv Any) UnPack(table flatbuffers.Table) *AnyT
```

title: [C#] support Object API
[Swift] Support create long string
body:
Hi, there

The `Fatal error: Not enough bits to represent the passed value` happened when I run `FlatBufferBuilder().create(string: String(repeating: "a", count: 257))`, it's was fixed.

please review it, thanks.

title: [Swift] create function & update documentation
body: The following PR updates the documentation for the swift implementation with the new `addVectorOf()` and adds the create function to the documentation. Furthermore, it adds the convenient create function that @mzaks requested in the last PR.

title: [C++] Fix for printing of enum in case output_enum_identifiers=1.
body:
This PR fixes the printing of bit_flags enum in case output_enum_identifiers=1.
Support of `bit_flags`+`case output_enum_identifiers` was added by #5454 (@ll-antn).
Unfortunately, we missed that #5454 didn't take into account a possible forward evolution of enums.
Numerical result of conversion `binary->json->binary` might depend on flag `output_enum_identifiers` and enum value.
The first commit adds a simple test case.
Let's imagine we receive a binary message with `color=(1u << 2) | Color_Blue | Color_Red)`.
If `output_enum_identifiers=false`, json output will be correct: `color: 13`.
But for `case output_enum_identifiers=true` it will be: `color: "Red Blue"`.
If convert this wrong JSON back into a binary message, the `(1u << 2)` flag will be lost.
This PR fixes it (function `PrintScalar`).

Other changes are refactoring to improve readability and performance.

title: Document JSON compatibility guarantees.
body: I think this captures the discussion on: https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/issues/5688

title: Added the code to embed the binary schema to the source (--bfbs-gen-embed).
body:
This is pulled forward from an old PR #5162 that will be closed.

I require to have access to the flatbuffer schemas in the shipped product I'm building. I find it hard to manage the schemas used in different libraries even with the bfbs format. I have many libraries (50+) built on various platforms (C++) and each have there own set of unique schemas. This make packaging the schemas after the build complicated. With the cross platform support, access to the schemas make it even more complicated.

This is an attempt to ensure the schema used to produce the generated code can also be stored in the source code and not rely on external files, zip, etc for the schema definition. The idea is to take the binary schema data and encode it into the generated source. That way the schema definition can optionally be part of the binaries (dll/exe/etc). This solves some of the cross platform packaging issues and also ensures the schemas will not be lost.

Using the following will generate code for the schema:
flatc.exe --cpp --bfbs-gen-embed monster.fbs

The binary schema can be accessed using the generated header file monster_bfbs_generated.h and the struct <root_type>BinarySchema.

See the example in sample/sample_bfbs.cpp  

Example

```
#include "monster_bfbs_generated.h" 

// Initialize parser by deserializing bfbs schema from source.
flatbuffers::Parser parser;
parser.Deserialize(MonsterBinarySchema::data(), MonsterBinarySchema::size());
```

title: (Optionally) add an additional suffix namespace to generated fbs files.
body:
This change allows for the generation of fbs files (from proto) that
don't contain name collisions with the protobuf generated C++ code,
allowing both the proto and fbs message types to be linked into the same binary.

title: [C++] Add CMake 'generated_code' target
body:
This PR simplifies resolving of build dependencies for CMake-based build.
The tests and the samples have dependencies which are manually declared in CMakeLists.txt. Due to possible mistakes in the declaration of dependencies, a compilation process may spuriously fail or lead to undefined behavior.
This PR adds a fake target `generated_code` which creates sync-barrier for targets that depend on generated code. In principle, we can delete from CMakeLists.txt all lines like this:
>`#file generate by running compiler on tests/monster_test.fbs`
>`${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/tests/monster_test_generated.h`

They are not necessary if a target already depends on the `generated code` target.
I’m sure that the current dependencies are defined correctly. However, the proposed changes could be helpful in the future.

title: [Java] Replace Table.UTF8_CHARSET with StandardCharsets.UTF_8
body: I am trying to use flatbuffers generated java code in GWT and is blocked by GWT's missing support for ThreadLocal.initialValue. Since StandardCharsets.UTF_8 is already used in other places and Charset is thread-safe this PR just removes Table.UTF8_CHARSET and replace all references to it with StandardCharsets.UTF_8.

title: Add flatc '--cpp_std' switch
wrap multiple statements in do {} while(!IsConstTrue(true))
body: To avoid problems mentioned in https://stackoverflow.com/questions/257418/do-while-0-what-is-it-good-for. Use `!IsConstTrue(true)` instead of `0` to avoid warning C4127.

title: [Dart] Fix prepare space for writeListInt64 and writeListUint64
body: Fix prepare space for writeListInt64 and writeListUint64.

title: Add --force-empty-vectors option
body:
The rationale for this option is that JSON clients typically want empty arrays (i.e [] in the JSON) instead of missing properties, but not empty strings when the value isn't set.
--force-empty is kept as-is, i.e. it will force both empty strings and vectors.

Closes #5652 

Most of the changes are whitespace, because `--force-empty-vectors` is the new longest option, so some CLI help text formatting was needed.

I'm not very familiar with the innards of the Flatbuffers source base, but works in local testing.

[docs]: add missing semicolon

title: Supress unsigned-integer-overflow for PaddingBytes
body:
Can't pinpoint but seen in the wild:

flatbuffers/base.h:386:23: runtime error: unsigned integer overflow: 18446744073709551615 + 1 cannot be represented in type 'unsigned long'

Which leads me to believe that this is not wrong input for this function and should be sanitizer supressed. But it's more of a guess than anything. @aardappel asked me to ping @vglavnyy for this issue.

title: [rust] Add use declarations to Rust-generated bindings for imported FB definitions
Remove a static_assert
body: Having a static_assert on MSAN and ASAN prevents the fuzzers from being used with different engines, like TSAN, UBSAN, … but also with fuzzers that aren't using MSAN/ASAN like afl for example.

title: Split Bazel targets into multiple packages

title: Simplify declarations of x-macro FLATBUFFERS_TD
body:
This PR introduce simplified declaration syntax of `FLATBUFFERS_TD` macros.
Each invocation of `FLATBUFFERS_TD` uses only necessary arguments of a type declaration.
This would make it easier to add new languages.

title: [C++] read vtable size through ReadScalar()
body: Use ReadScalar() to read vtable size in order to avoid getting wrong value on big endian machine.

title: [C++] Changed null checks in test. Removed verifier pointer usage.
body: Fixes for the [null checks](https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/pull/5611#issuecomment-554625837) in MSVC2019 #5611

title: Add testing of C++ with sanitizers (CI-Docker)
body:
This PR adds testing of C++ code with two full-featured compilers (GCC-8.3, Clang-7.0) and sanitizers.
The PR is based on the #5130 PR by @neomantra.

Changes:
- the base of the container is updated to Debian Buster
- GCC=8.3.0
- Clang=7.0.1
- the test runs both GCC and Clang for testing
- added `--cap-add SYS_PTRACE` required by the leak-sanitizer

With these two additional targets the execution time grown from 10 to 14 minutes.

title: Fix ambiguity of a type deduction in TEST_EQ macro for `enum class` args.
body:
Before this PR this code  (in the `test.cpp`) was impossible:
```cpp
enum class TestEnum : int8_t {  A, B };
TEST_EQ(MyGame::Example::TestEnum::A, Foo());
```

Due to ambiguity of type deduction, this code caused a compilation error like this:
>error C2679: binary '<<': no operator found which takes a right-hand operand of type 'T' (or there is no acceptable conversion) with [ T=MyGame::Example::TestEnum  ]
.... (listing of all possible specializations)

This is a well-known problem (C++ DR1601):
- http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg21/docs/cwg_defects.html#1601
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34336024/ambiguous-overload-when-writing-an-enum-with-an-enum-base-but-only-with-clang

However, all modern compilers break the rule C++17 16.4.2 introduced by DR 1601:
>A conversion that promotes an enumeration whose underlying type is fixed to its underlying type is better than one that promotes to the promoted underlying type, if the two are different.

This PR adds a workaround and allows the use of simple checking of `enum class` values in tests:
```cpp
TEST_EQ(MyGame::Example::TestEnum::A, MyGame::Example::TestEnum::B);
```

title: [C++] add namespace prefix in FLATBUFFERS_MAX_BUFFER_SIZE
body: add `::flatbuffers::` before `soffset_t` in `FLATBUFFERS_MAX_BUFFER_SIZE` so that this macro can be used outside the flatbuffers namespace.

title: [C++] Moved content of idl_gen_general.cpp to code_generators.cpp
body:
- Moved code from `idl_gen_general.cpp` into `code_generators.cpp`.
- Renamed `GeneralMakeRule` into `JavaCSharpMakeRule`.
- Removed references to `GeneralMakeRule` for languages that don't support it.
- Raise an error when using the `-M` option for a language that doesn't support it.
- clang-format picked up some missed formats in `idl_gen_java` that i just included here as well

title: [Lua] Library improvements
body:
Realized `view.lua#Offset()` is in a hot path and optimized it to avoid a bunch of needless lookups. I first cache the location to the vtable (instead of calculating it everytime) and inlined the unpacking function. 

This lead me to optimized most of the `view.lua` file to reduce lookups and use local functions as much as possible. I also hardcoded a lot of values that will never change, again to avoid lookups.

The profiling tests show almost a 2x improvement in traversing the flatbuffer data.

**Before**:

```
built 100 512-byte flatbuffers in 0.03sec: 3.67/msec, 1.79MB/sec
built 1000 512-byte flatbuffers in 0.22sec: 4.62/msec, 2.26MB/sec
built 10000 512-byte flatbuffers in 2.17sec: 4.61/msec, 2.25MB/sec
traversed 100 440-byte flatbuffers in 0.01sec: 15.10/msec, 6.34MB/sec
traversed 1000 440-byte flatbuffers in 0.07sec: 14.80/msec, 6.21MB/sec
traversed 10000 440-byte flatbuffers in 0.69sec: 14.40/msec, 6.04MB/sec
Number of test passed: 10 / 10 (100.00%)
```

**After**:

```
built 100 512-byte flatbuffers in 0.03sec: 2.95/msec, 1.44MB/sec
built 1000 512-byte flatbuffers in 0.20sec: 4.96/msec, 2.42MB/sec
built 10000 512-byte flatbuffers in 1.93sec: 5.17/msec, 2.53MB/sec
built 10000 512-byte flatbuffers in 1.52sec: 6.59/msec, 3.22MB/sec
traversed 100 440-byte flatbuffers in 0.00sec: 26.85/msec, 11.27MB/sec
traversed 1000 440-byte flatbuffers in 0.04sec: 26.30/msec, 11.03MB/sec
traversed 10000 440-byte flatbuffers in 0.36sec: 27.40/msec, 11.50MB/sec
Number of test passed: 11 / 11 (100.00%)

```

title: add check for root_type specified for json schema generation
body:
Hi! As recommended [here](https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/issues/5615) I've added simple check to avoid segfault. In my opinion this solution currently misses user friendly error message, but I dont see any example near this place in codebase for propagating error message. Can you advise me how to properly do this? Also I'll be glad to add test for change I made, so the question is what is the best place for such test? Can I simply add fbs file without root_type and test return code of flatc in generate_code.sh or something else?

Also recommendations for PR says:
> For any C++ changes, please make sure to run `sh src/clang-format-git.sh`

Firstly script is renamed to just `clang-format.sh` and after I launched it there are format related changes to code that is not related to my changes. So definetly this check should be in CI to protect the health of the codebase.

title: [C++, C#, Java] Separated C# and Java generators into their own classes
body:
The C# and Java code generators are located together in the `src/idl_gen_general.cpp` file and it is becoming harder to extend the generators for either language. It is suggested to break the Java and C# generators into their own classes to match the other language generators.

This is the first PR for separating them. The `idl_gen_general.cpp` was cloned to `idl_gen_csharp.cpp` and the java logic removed. Some minor refactoring was also performed, but the structure is the same.  A follow up PR will rework the Java generator in a similar manner.

The LOC for the C# generator went from 1830 -> 1183 lines.

Tested: ran `flattest` and `tests/generate_code.sh` and there were no changes to the generated files. Also ran `sh src/clang-format-git.sh`.

Oddly, I had to delete a rouge? comment at then end of `test/test.cpp#InvalidNestedFlatbufferTest` that caused running `clang-format` to produce a non-buildable source. Another bug with clang-format? (clang-format v.5).

Ran both `flattests` and `test/generate_code.sh`.

title: Flatbuffers Python Object API
body:
Implement the logic to generate the Python object API that can
unpack the data from a buf class into an object class, and pack
the data of an object class to a buf class.

Thank you for submitting a PR!

Please make sure you include the names of the affected language(s) in your PR title.
This helps us get the correct maintainers to look at your issue.

If you make changes to any of the code generators, be sure to run
`cd tests && sh generate_code.sh` (or equivalent .bat) and include the generated
code changes in the PR. This allows us to better see the effect of the PR.

If your PR includes C++ code, please adhere to the Google C++ Style Guide,
and don't forget we try to support older compilers (e.g. VS2010, GCC 4.6.3),
so only some C++11 support is available.

Include other details as appropriate.

Thanks!

title: Change monster_extra generation to use flatbuffers::unique_ptr
body:
Updated `generate_code.{bat|sh}` to use `flatbuffers::unique_ptr` instead of `std::unique_ptr`.

Fixes #5609

title: [C++] Adds basic schema evolution tests
body:
This change adds some basic schema evolution tests in C++. It verifies that the proper evolution of a schema is valid in a backwards- and forwards-compatible manner. It also checks that the `Verifiers` for the multiple versions of the schema can correctly read new and old data.

It adds two schema, that are properly evolved from each other. The second version of the schema is annotated with the changes from the first version. The generated C++ headers for those schema are also included. 

I tried to test the most common evolution points:

- Field deprecation
- Field reordering using the `id` attribute
- Field additions
- Union additions
- Enum additions
- Field renaming

Tests: `flattest` runs successfully.

For a follow up to this PR, tests should be added to test improper evolution of schema.

I would also take suggestions on other tests that should be performed.

title: include/flatbuffers/base.h: fix no_sanitize issue with old clang
body:
Older clang versions raise:
```
./flatbuffers/base.h:365:1: error: unknown attribute 'no_sanitize' ignored [-Werror,-Wattributes]
__supress_ubsan__("alignment")
^
./flatbuffers/base.h:246:50: note: expanded from macro '__supress_ubsan__'
  #define __supress_ubsan__(type) __attribute__((no_sanitize(type)))
                                                 ^
```

Comparing https://releases.llvm.org/3.6.0/tools/clang/docs/AttributeReference.html
with https://releases.llvm.org/3.7.0/tools/clang/docs/AttributeReference.html
shows that __attribute__((no_sanitize(type))) is available since 3.7.0

title: [C++] Refactor to conform to Google C++ style guide
body:
This refactor conforms all the C++ code to follow the [Google C++ style guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html) which is the requested [style of flatbuffers](https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md). 

This change was done by automated code formatting tools and introduces no logical changes.

The majority of the changes are:

- Line limits to [80 characters](https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Line_Length)
- [Horizontal spacing](https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Horizontal_Whitespace)
- Proper indentation [2 space](https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Spaces_vs._Tabs)
- Ordering and spacing of [includes](https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Names_and_Order_of_Includes)
- [Expression consistency](https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Pointer_and_Reference_Expressions)
   - The asterisk and ampersand symbols are all aligned to the variable name. Though alignment to the type is OK as well.

Tested: `flattest` ran successfully and `test/generate_code.sh` produced no changes to generated files.

I grouped the refactors into separate commits, in case we want to merge them separately. I can squash them if required.

title: flatbuffers.h: fix documentation warning
body:
Fixes following clang -Wdocumentation warning:
```
flatbuffers.h:1762:17: error: parameter ']' not found in the function declaration [-Werror,-Wdocumentation]
  /// @param[in]] v A const reference to the `std::vector` of structs to
```

title: [Lua] Adds Clear() method to builder to enable reusable builders
body:
Adds a method to clear the state of the Lua FlatBufferBuilder object so that it can be reused to construct multiple objects. This is an optimization over using multiple builders, since this new method just resets a few state variables and doesn't do any new allocations.

Fixes #5502 

Usage:

After using a `flatbuffer.Builder()` to encode a schema, one would call `builder:Clear()` to reset the internal state of the builder so it can be used again immediately. 

Tested: Added new Lua tests to ensure a 'cleared' builder produces the same output as a new builder. Passes all existing Lua tests.

title: [Kotlin] Fix union vector accessor after change in Java API
body:
Kolin uses java library as dependency, which changed the way it access union vector recently (e365c502ffc659752f9b7a8d60b0052a07e33659).

 This changes updates kotlin code generation to match Java's changes.

title: [flatc] Remove an always true condition for flexbuffers
body:
The condition was unnecessary and Detected by

PVS-Studio
V560 [CWE-571] A part of conditional expression is always true: !opts.use_flexbuffers. flatc.cpp 438

title: [Swift] Swift implementation 🎉🎉
[GO] Fix support for enums with underscores and Unions with imported members
body:
This PR fixes two bugs:

- Fixes #5481: 

- Fixes #5602 (regression introduced by #5339)

title: [C++, Java, C#, TypeScript, JavaScript] Skip generation of mutable union types
body:
When using the `--gen-mutable` flag with schema that contains unions, the code generated would include a method to mutate the union type. Unions are immutable and therefore the type field of a union should also be immutable.

This change removes the generation of these mutable methods for all the languages that can handle mutable flatbuffers.

Added a `IsUnion(Type)` method, and colocated it with the other `Is___` methods. This required moving them below `EnumDef` to avoid a forward declaration.

No tests are needed, the generated code from `tests/generate_code.sh` showed that the 'mutate_xxx_type` methods are removed and nothing else changes.

title: [Go] Add UnPackTo functions
body: This adds an `UnPackTo` function to the Go object API, analogous to the C++ one, that unpacks into an existing object.  The `UnPack` functions use this to do the heavy lifting.

title: Bugfix for Rust generation of union fields named with language keywords
body:
Looking at ParseField, it appears that in the case of unions, an extra field with a `UnionTypeFieldSuffix` is added to the type definition, however, if the name of this field is a keyword in the target language, it isn't escaped.

For example, if generating code for rust for a union field named `type`, flatc will generate a (non-keyword escaped) field named `type_type` for this hidden union field, and one (keyword escaped) called `type_` for the actual union contents.

When the union accessors are generated, they refer to this `type_type` field, but they will escape it mistakenly, generating code like this:

```
  #[inline]
  #[allow(non_snake_case)]
  pub fn type__as_int(&self) -> Option<Int<'a>> {
    if self.type__type() == Type::Int {
      self.type_().map(|u| Int::init_from_table(u))
    } else {
      None
    }
  }
```

Which will fail to build because the field is called `self.type_type()`, not `self.type__type()`.

Thank you for submitting a PR!

Please make sure you include the names of the affected language(s) in your PR title.
This helps us get the correct maintainers to look at your issue.

If you make changes to any of the code generators, be sure to run
`cd tests && sh generate_code.sh` (or equivalent .bat) and include the generated
code changes in the PR. This allows us to better see the effect of the PR.

If your PR includes C++ code, please adhere to the Google C++ Style Guide,
and don't forget we try to support older compilers (e.g. VS2010, GCC 4.6.3),
so only some C++11 support is available.

Include other details as appropriate.

Thanks!

title: Fix typos in comments
body:
Found by the https://github.com/OSGeo/gdal/blob/master/gdal/scripts/fix_typos.sh
script on the internal copy of flatbuffers inside GDAL

title: [Java] Add ByteBuffer copy for vector of bytes
body:
There wasn't an efficient way to copy data from a Java `ByteBuffer` into a flatbuffer without incurring an additional memcopy to an intermediary `byte[]`.  This change adds two new static methods to the Java `FlatBufferBuilder` to improve this. 

First is a method that takes a `byte[]` with an `offset` and `length`, so that large `byte[]` doesn't have to be copied to an intermediary before being copied into the `FlatBufferBuilder` internal buffer. Secondly, a method that takes `ByteBuffer` is provided, as internally the `FlatBufferBuilder` using a `ByteBuffer` for storage. This method then can rely on the efficiency of the `ByteBuffer.put(ByteBuffer other)` copy. This should handle 'direct' and native `ByteBuffer`s as well as buffers with different limits and position markers.

This change also updates the Java generation code for `byte[]` fields to internally use those new static methods described above.  Previously the code generation generated for-loop and added each element one at a time; this comes with increased overhead costs of the extra method invocations. 

Added Tests to the JavaTest.java file that test different type of copies.

**Performance gains:**

Copied 1 MB `byte[]` 1,000 times.

Original implementation: avg = 2.4 ms / copy
New implementation: avg = 0.1 ms / copy

Which is roughly a **~25x** speed up. Mileage may vary for smaller arrays, but in my tests the new implementation never ran slower than the original.

title: [C++] Verifier for evolved union fields should return true for unknown values.
body:
The C++ flatbuffer verifier returns `false` if it encounters an unknown union field. This should not be the case as unknown union fields are OK in a forward compatible evolution of the schema.

```
union Any_V1 { Monster, Weapon, Pickup }
union Any_V2 { Monster, Weapon, Pickup, Armor }
```

Generating a flatbuffer with an Any_V2 union will return 'false' in the verifier generated against the Any_V1 union schema. 

This change will now skip unknown union fields by returning `true` for them. This is fine since the older schema wouldn't known about these new union fields anyway and wouldn't 'parse' them.

Note: No tests were provided because there are no existing schema evolution tests. This is [known issue](https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/projects/16#card-28306986). The chance of this change breaking things is extremely low, since it is only in the verifier that is not required to be used.

title: Rust: Add idiomatic iterator for Vector type
body:
This PR is a reimplementation of the same functionality and API present in #5166.

It improves upon that PR in the following ways:
* This implementation is more efficient, as it only reads the length once instead of in every call to `.next()`.
* This implementation also provides more efficient versions of `fn nth(...)` and `fn size_hint(...)` instead relying on the default implementation.
* This implementation also implements `DoubleEndedIterator`, `ExactSizeIterator`, `FusedIterator`.

The tests have been copied verbatim from #5166, but extended with tests for checking that `DoubleEndedIterator` has also been implementation correctly.

Note: This PR contains a commit, which is also a part of #5577. Feel free to either accept the related PR first, or close it and deal with both commits here.

title: Rust: Fix Copy and Clone impls for a few generic types
body:
The `Copy` and `Clone` impls for some of the generic types are too strict. This manually implements the traits for `WIPOffset`, `ForwardsUOffset` and `Vector` to remove the bound on the inner type.

The changes from `&self` to `self` in a few functions is to satisfy clippy. See [this](https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#trivially_copy_pass_by_ref) for context.

title: Add `--clean-first` to the cmake-build command (travis)
body:
This PR  is the finalization of previous PR #5573.

Argument `--clean-first` added to the `cmake --build` command to simulate `make clean` before building. This should surface issues with the tests in the early stages.
The `--clean-first` runs `clean` target to remove previously generated files.
The `clean` target removes all `_generated.h` files before the compilation started.
If all dependencies scripted well, these files will be created before the `flattests` compilation starts.

Missed `monster_extra_generated.h` file was added to the `flattests` target.

title: Fix issue #5557
body:
This PR remove not necessary dependency from the `sample bfbs.cpp` file.

The `sample bfbs.cpp` includes not necessary file `monster_test generated.h`.
But this file isn't part of the corresponding source list (`${FlatBuffers_Sample_BFBS_SRCS}`).
This unexpected inclusion is not taken into account by the dependency resolution system.
If this file is really needed, then it should be part of the `sample_bfbs` target.

title: Avoid intentional unsigned integer overflow getting caught by sanitizers
body: Workaround found at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33351891/how-to-suppress-some-unsigned-integer-overflow-errors-from-ubsan

body: Since Flatbuffers don't support null items in vectors of tables.

title: [Java] byte buffer factory returned buffer capcity is used instead of the requested size
body: Fixes unexpected behavior on unmatching requested vs returned grown byte buffer size

title: [FlexBuffers][Java] Cache size of Sized objects in FlexBuffers
body:
In my benchmarks it shows deserialization performance improvements of
around 7%

Related to issue #5541

title: #5544 Fix of Array of table is not sorted if Create<type>Direct() is used
body:
Fix #5544.

Notice that "ofSorted" methods can't use const. They want to sort the vector.

title: Fix namespaced struct/field name collision detection (#5540)
body:
Changes the use of `LookupStruct` to `LookupCreateStruct` in
`ParseField` to also detect when collisions happen in namespaces.

Solution as given by @aardappel. Fixes #5540.

title: [Java][FlexBuffers] Fix Sized::size() one empty objects returning exception
body:
Empty objects that inherit from Sized would try to access internal
ByteBuffer when Sized::size was called. So we add a single byte in
the empty buffer, so when size() is called it would return 0

Fix #5542

title: Update Rust versions under test from 1.30.1 to 1.37.0
[FlexBuffers][Java] Add override Key::toString
body: Fix issue #5531

title: [FlexBuffers][Java] Fix wrong access to a string using Reference::asS…
body:
…tring().

The real position of a string is  calculated by using the indirect() method,
which should be based on parentWidth and not byteWidth, as it was implemented.

We are also fixing the flag BUILDER_FLAG_SHARE_STRINGS on FlexBuffersBuilder
that was set as '1', the same value as BUILDER_FLAG_SHARE_KEYS.

Fix issue #5528

title: Adds XOPEN_SOURCE for PATH_MAX and POSIX 1993 for stat
body: These are the only two required extension for compilation of flatbuffers using -std=c++11 instead of gnu++11. This makes it explicit where and why these extensions are required.

title: Fix Mutate() methods of Array<scalar/struct> (override 5508)
body:
This PR overrides #5508.
@svenk177 could you review changes?

title: [C++] Fixed DetachedBuffer self move assignment
[flac] Add FlexBuffers option for generating data
body: Alongside --binary and --json, an additional switch (--flexbuffers) can be passed to convert data using FlexBuffers.

body:

title: Add element size parameter to __vector_as_arraysegment [c#]
body:
Add element size parameter to __vector_as_arraysegment fixing issue where VectorAsBytes returns incorrect size span for multibyte element types.

Potential solution for: https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/issues/5511

title: Annotate getters with @Pure when --java-checkerframework is specified.
body:
Together with @Nullable, this allows users to use static analysis tools
like CheckerFramework to catch NPEs caused by unset fields.

Thank you for submitting a PR!

Please make sure you include the names of the affected language(s) in your PR title.
This helps us get the correct maintainers to look at your issue.

If you make changes to any of the code generators, be sure to run
`cd tests && sh generate_code.sh` (or equivalent .bat) and include the generated
code changes in the PR. This allows us to better see the effect of the PR.

If your PR includes C++ code, please adhere to the Google C++ Style Guide,
and don't forget we try to support older compilers (e.g. VS2010, GCC 4.6.3),
so only some C++11 support is available.

Include other details as appropriate.

Thanks!
